purpose.p: An interface is the specification for a designed interaction between one or more co-functioning products. In some industries, this is referred to as the Interface Control which provides the procedures and documentation necessary for the identification and management of functional and physical characteristics between two or more products.
An interface defines the product attributes that exist at a common boundary of two or more products. An interface does not have to be physical.
purpose.example: Example: An induction coil interface is a collapsing magnetic field.
purpose.p: An interface is treated the same as a product. It has an identification, version, and definition. An interface is always related to a product or products through the product_identification, product_version, and product_view_definition. The interface may be either a design, planned, or realized.

The interface also includes any connecting parts, interface_connector, that are not identified in the product_structure of any of the parts that are interfaced. For example, a gasket that creates a seal between a pump and a flange may be identified as belonging to the interface rather than as a part of the pump or a part or the flange.
The interface_connector is part of a product that performs the role of an interface.
purpose.example: Example: The socket on an electrical plug
purpose.p: The interface_connector is used to associate interface characteristics with a product. The interface_connector is also related to a product through the product_identification, product_version, and product_definition.
Interfaces with the environment should be treated as product attributes or characteristics. For example, a product heating the surrounding area during its normal operation.

inscope.p: All products that have a common boundary or interaction with another product.

outscope.p: All products that do not interact or have a common boundary with another product. A product's interface with the environment is out of scope.
